column2: Reply Obj. 4: Among the first created things are to be reckoned those which have a general relationship to things.
column3: Reply o b j. four: Among the first created things are to be reckoned those which have a general relationship to things.

column2: And, therefore, among these time must be included, as having the nature of a common measure; but not movement, which is related only to the movable subject.
column3: And, therefore, among these time must be included, as having the nature of a common measure; but not movement, which is related only to the movable subject.

column2: Reply Obj. 5: Place is implied as existing in the empyrean heaven, this being the boundary of the universe.
column3: Reply o b j. five: Place is implied as existing in the empyrean heaven, this being the boundary of the universe.

column2: And since place has reference to things permanent, it was created at once in its totality.
column3: And since place has reference to things permanent, it was created at once in its totality.

column2: But time, as not being permanent, was created in its beginning: even as actually we cannot lay hold of any part of time save the "now." _______________________
column3: But time, as not being permanent, was created in its beginning: even as actually we cannot lay hold of any part of time save the "now." , blank ,

column2: QUESTION 67
column3: QUESTION sixty seven

column2: ON THE WORK OF DISTINCTION IN ITSELF (In Four Articles)
column3: ON THE WORK OF DISTINCTION IN ITSELF (In Four Articles)

column2: We must consider next the work of distinction in itself.
column3: We must consider next the work of distinction in itself.

column2: First, the work of the first day; secondly, the work of the second day; thirdly the work of the third day.
column3: First, the work of the first day; secondly, the work of the second day; thirdly the work of the third day.

column2: Under the first head there are four points of inquiry:
column3: Under the first head there are four points of inquiry:

column2: (1) Whether the word light is used in its proper sense in speaking of spiritual things?
column3: (one) Whether the word light is used in its proper sense in speaking of spiritual things?

column2: (2) Whether light, in corporeal things, is itself corporeal?
column3: (two) Whether light, in corporeal things, is itself corporeal?

column2: (3) Whether light is a quality?
column3: (three) Whether light is a quality?

column2: (4) Whether light was fittingly made on the first day? _______________________
column3: (four) Whether light was fittingly made on the first day? , blank ,

column2: FIRST ARTICLE [I, Q. 67, Art. 1]
column3: FIRST ARTICLE [I, q sixty seven, Art. one]

column2: Whether the Word "Light" Is Used in Its Proper Sense in Speaking of Spiritual Things?
column3: Whether the Word "Light" Is Used in Its Proper Sense in Speaking of Spiritual Things?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that "light" is used in its proper sense in spiritual things.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that "light" is used in its proper sense in spiritual things.

column2: For Augustine says (Gen. ad lit.
column3: For Augustine says (Gen. ad lit.

column2: iv, 28) that "in spiritual things light is better and surer: and that Christ is not called Light in the same sense as He is called the Stone; the former is to be taken literally, and the latter metaphorically."
column3: i v, twenty eight) that "in spiritual things light is better and surer: and that Christ is not called Light in the same sense as He is called the Stone; the former is to be taken literally, and the latter metaphorically."

column2: Obj. 2: Further, Dionysius (Div.
column3: o b j. two: Further, Dionysius (d i v.

column2: Nom. iv) includes Light among the intellectual names of God.
column3: Nom. i v) includes Light among the intellectual names of God.

column2: But such names are used in their proper sense in spiritual things.
column3: But such names are used in their proper sense in spiritual things.

column2: Therefore light is used in its proper sense in spiritual matters.
column3: Therefore light is used in its proper sense in spiritual matters.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, the Apostle says (Eph. 5:13): "All that is made manifest is light." But to be made manifest belongs more properly to spiritual things than to corporeal.
column3: o b j. three: Further, the Apostle says (e p h. five thirteen): "All that is made manifest is light." But to be made manifest belongs more properly to spiritual things than to corporeal.

column2: Therefore also does light.
column3: Therefore also does light.

column2: _On the contrary,_ Ambrose says (De Fide ii) that "Splendor" is among those things which are said of God metaphorically.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore Ambrose says (De Fide ii) that "Splendor" is among those things which are said of God metaphorically.

column2: _I answer that,_ Any word may be used in two ways--that is to say, either in its original application or in its more extended meaning. This is clearly shown in the word "sight," originally applied to the act of the sense, and then, as sight is the noblest and most trustworthy of the senses, extended in common speech to all knowledge obtained through the other senses.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore Any word may be used in two ways-that is to say, either in its original application or in its more extended meaning. This is clearly shown in the word "sight," originally applied to the act of the sense, and then, as sight is the noblest and most trustworthy of the senses, extended in common speech to all knowledge obtained through the other senses.

column2: Thus we say, "Seeing how it tastes," or "smells," or "burns." Further, sight is applied to knowledge obtained through the intellect, as in those words: "Blessed are the clean of heart, for they shall see God" (Matt.
column3: Thus we say, "Seeing how it tastes," or "smells," or "burns." Further, sight is applied to knowledge obtained through the intellect, as in those words: "Blessed are the clean of heart, for they shall see God" (Matt.
five to eight).

column2: And thus it is with the word light.
column3: And thus it is with the word light.

column2: In its primary meaning it signifies that which makes manifest to the sense of sight; afterwards it was extended to that which makes manifest to cognition of any kind.
column3: In its primary meaning it signifies that which makes manifest to the sense of sight; afterwards it was extended to that which makes manifest to cognition of any kind.

column2: If, then, the word is taken in its strict and primary meaning, it is to be understood metaphorically when applied to spiritual things, as Ambrose says (De Fide ii).
column3: If, then, the word is taken in its strict and primary meaning, it is to be understood metaphorically when applied to spiritual things, as Ambrose says (De Fide ii).

column2: But if taken in its common and extended use, as applied to manifestation of every kind, it may properly be applied to spiritual things.
column3: But if taken in its common and extended use, as applied to manifestation of every kind, it may properly be applied to spiritual things.

column2: The answer to the objections will sufficiently appear from what has been said. _______________________
column3: The answer to the objections will sufficiently appear from what has been said. , blank ,

column2: SECOND ARTICLE [I, Q. 67, Art. 2]
column3: SECOND ARTICLE [I, q sixty seven, Art. two]

column2: Whether Light Is a Body?
column3: Whether Light Is a Body?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that light is a body.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that light is a body.

column2: For Augustine says (De Lib.
column3: For Augustine says (De Lib.

column2: Arb. iii, 5) that "light takes the first place among bodies."Therefore light is a body.
column3: Arb. iii, five) that "light takes the first place among bodies."Therefore light is a body.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, the Philosopher says (Topic. v, 2) that "light is a species of fire." But fire is a body, and therefore so is light.
column3: o b j. two: Further, the Philosopher says (Topic. v, two) that "light is a species of fire." But fire is a body, and therefore so is light.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, the powers of movement, intersection, reflection, belong properly to bodies; and all these are attributes of light and its rays.
column3: o b j. three: Further, the powers of movement, intersection, reflection, belong properly to bodies; and all these are attributes of light and its rays.

column2: Moreover, different rays of light, as Dionysius says (Div. Nom.
column3: Moreover, different rays of light, as Dionysius says (d i v. Nom.

column2: ii) are united and separated, which seems impossible unless they are bodies.
column3: ii) are united and separated, which seems impossible unless they are bodies.

column2: Therefore light is a body.
column3: Therefore light is a body.

column2: _On the contrary,_ Two bodies cannot occupy the same place simultaneously.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore Two bodies cannot occupy the same place simultaneously.

column2: But this is the case with light and air.
column3: But this is the case with light and air.

column2: Therefore light is not a body.
column3: Therefore light is not a body.

column2: _I answer that,_ Light cannot be a body, for three evident reasons. First, on the part of place.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore Light cannot be a body, for three evident reasons. First, on the part of place.

column2: For the place of any one body is different from that of any other, nor is it possible, naturally speaking, for any two bodies of whatever nature, to exist simultaneously in the same place; since contiguity requires distinction of place.
column3: For the place of any one body is different from that of any other, nor is it possible, naturally speaking, for any two bodies of whatever nature, to exist simultaneously in the same place; since contiguity requires distinction of place.

column2: The second reason is from movement.
column3: The second reason is from movement.

column2: For if light were a body, its diffusion would be the local movement of a body.
column3: For if light were a body, its diffusion would be the local movement of a body.

column2: Now no local movement of a body can be instantaneous, as everything that moves from one place to another must pass through the intervening space before reaching the end: whereas the diffusion of light is instantaneous.
column3: Now no local movement of a body can be instantaneous, as everything that moves from one place to another must pass through the intervening space before reaching the end: whereas the diffusion of light is instantaneous.

column2: Nor can it be argued that the time required is too short to be perceived; for though this may be the case in short distances, it cannot be so in distances so great as that which separates the East from the West.
column3: Nor can it be argued that the time required is too short to be perceived; for though this may be the case in short distances, it cannot be so in distances so great as that which separates the East from the West.

column2: Yet as soon as the sun is at the horizon, the whole hemisphere is illuminated from end to end.
column3: Yet as soon as the sun is at the horizon, the whole hemisphere is illuminated from end to end.

column2: It must also be borne in mind on the part of movement that whereas all bodies have their natural determinate movement, that of light is indifferent as regards direction, working equally in a circle as in a straight line.
column3: It must also be borne in mind on the part of movement that whereas all bodies have their natural determinate movement, that of light is indifferent as regards direction, working equally in a circle as in a straight line.

column2: Hence it appears that the diffusion of light is not the local movement of a body.
column3: Hence it appears that the diffusion of light is not the local movement of a body.

column2: The third reason is from generation and corruption.
column3: The third reason is from generation and corruption.

column2: For if light were a body, it would follow that whenever the air is darkened by the absence of the luminary, the body of light would be corrupted, and its matter would receive a new form.
column3: For if light were a body, it would follow that whenever the air is darkened by the absence of the luminary, the body of light would be corrupted, and its matter would receive a new form.

column2: But unless we are to say that darkness is a body, this does not appear to be the case.
column3: But unless we are to say that darkness is a body, this does not appear to be the case.

column2: Neither does it appear from what matter a body can be daily generated large enough to fill the intervening hemisphere.
column3: Neither does it appear from what matter a body can be daily generated large enough to fill the intervening hemisphere.

column2: Also it would be absurd to say that a body of so great a bulk is corrupted by the mere absence of the luminary.
column3: Also it would be absurd to say that a body of so great a bulk is corrupted by the mere absence of the luminary.

column2: And should anyone reply that it is not corrupted, but approaches and moves around with the sun, we may ask why it is that when a lighted candle is obscured by the intervening object the whole room is darkened?
column3: And should anyone reply that it is not corrupted, but approaches and moves around with the sun, we may ask why it is that when a lighted candle is obscured by the intervening object the whole room is darkened?

column2: It is not that the light is condensed round the candle when this is done, since it burns no more brightly then than it burned before.
column3: It is not that the light is condensed round the candle when this is done, since it burns no more brightly then than it burned before.

column2: Since, therefore, these things are repugnant, not only to reason, but to common sense, we must conclude that light cannot be a body.
column3: Since, therefore, these things are repugnant, not only to reason, but to common sense, we must conclude that light cannot be a body.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: Augustine takes light to be a luminous body in act--in other words, to be fire, the noblest of the four elements.
column3: Reply o b j. one: Augustine takes light to be a luminous body in act-in other words, to be fire, the noblest of the four elements.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: Aristotle pronounces light to be fire existing in its own proper matter: just as fire in aerial matter is "flame," or in earthly matter is "burning coal." Nor must too much attention be paid to the instances adduced by Aristotle in his works on logic, as he merely mentions them as the more or less probable opinions of various writers.
column3: Reply o b j. two: Aristotle pronounces light to be fire existing in its own proper matter: just as fire in aerial matter is "flame," or in earthly matter is "burning coal." Nor must too much attention be paid to the instances adduced by Aristotle in his works on logic, as he merely mentions them as the more or less probable opinions of various writers.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: All these properties are assigned to light metaphorically, and might in the same way be attributed to heat.
column3: Reply o b j. three: All these properties are assigned to light metaphorically, and might in the same way be attributed to heat.

column2: For because movement from place to place is naturally first in the order of movement as is proved _Phys._ viii, text.
column3: For because movement from place to place is naturally first in the order of movement as is proved underscore Phys.underscore viii, text.

column2: 55, we use terms belonging to local movement in speaking of alteration and movement of all kinds.
column3: fifty five, we use terms belonging to local movement in speaking of alteration and movement of all kinds.

column2: For even the word distance is derived from the idea of remoteness of place, to that of all contraries, as is said _Metaph._ x, text.
column3: For even the word distance is derived from the idea of remoteness of place, to that of all contraries, as is said underscore Metaph.underscore x, text.
thirteen. , blank ,

column2: THIRD ARTICLE [I, Q. 67, Art. 3]
column3: THIRD ARTICLE [I, q sixty seven, Art. three]

column2: Whether Light Is a Quality?
column3: Whether Light Is a Quality?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that light is not a quality.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that light is not a quality.

column2: For every quality remains in its subject, though the active cause of the quality be removed, as heat remains in water removed from the fire. But light does not remain in the air when the source of light is withdrawn.
column3: For every quality remains in its subject, though the active cause of the quality be removed, as heat remains in water removed from the fire. But light does not remain in the air when the source of light is withdrawn.

column2: Therefore light is not a quality.
column3: Therefore light is not a quality.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, every sensible quality has its opposite, as cold is opposed to heat, blackness to whiteness.
column3: o b j. two: Further, every sensible quality has its opposite, as cold is opposed to heat, blackness to whiteness.

column2: But this is not the case with light since darkness is merely a privation of light.
column3: But this is not the case with light since darkness is merely a privation of light.

column2: Light therefore is not a sensible quality.
column3: Light therefore is not a sensible quality.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, a cause is more potent than its effect.
column3: o b j. three: Further, a cause is more potent than its effect.

column2: But the light of the heavenly bodies is a cause of substantial forms of earthly bodies, and also gives to colors their immaterial being, by making them actually visible.
column3: But the light of the heavenly bodies is a cause of substantial forms of earthly bodies, and also gives to colors their immaterial being, by making them actually visible.

column2: Light, then, is not a sensible quality, but rather a substantial or spiritual form.
column3: Light, then, is not a sensible quality, but rather a substantial or spiritual form.

column2: _On the contrary,_ Damascene (De Fide Orth. i) says that light is a species of quality.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore Damascene (De Fide Orth. i) says that light is a species of quality.

column2: _I answer that,_ Some writers have said that the light in the air has not a natural being such as the color on a wall has, but only an intentional being, as a similitude of color in the air.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore Some writers have said that the light in the air has not a natural being such as the color on a wall has, but only an intentional being, as a similitude of color in the air.

column2: But this cannot be the case for two reasons.
column3: But this cannot be the case for two reasons.

column2: First, because light gives a name to the air, since by it the air becomes actually luminous.
column3: First, because light gives a name to the air, since by it the air becomes actually luminous.

column2: But color does not do this, for we do not speak of the air as colored.
column3: But color does not do this, for we do not speak of the air as colored.

column2: Secondly, because light produces natural effects, for by the rays of the sun bodies are warmed, and natural changes cannot be brought about by mere intentions.
column3: Secondly, because light produces natural effects, for by the rays of the sun bodies are warmed, and natural changes cannot be brought about by mere intentions.

column2: Others have said that light is the sun's substantial form, but this also seems impossible for two reasons.
column3: Others have said that light is the sun's substantial form, but this also seems impossible for two reasons.

column2: First, because substantial forms are not of themselves objects of the senses; for the object of the intellect is what a thing is, as is said _De Anima_ iii, text. 26: whereas light is visible of itself.
column3: First, because substantial forms are not of themselves objects of the senses; for the object of the intellect is what a thing is, as is said underscore De Anima underscore iii, text. twenty six: whereas light is visible of itself.

column2: In the second place, because it is impossible that what is the substantial form of one thing should be the accidental form of another; since substantial forms of their very nature constitute species: wherefore the substantial form always and everywhere accompanies the species.
column3: In the second place, because it is impossible that what is the substantial form of one thing should be the accidental form of another; since substantial forms of their very nature constitute species: wherefore the substantial form always and everywhere accompanies the species.

column2: But light is not the substantial form of air, for if it were, the air would be destroyed when light is withdrawn.
column3: But light is not the substantial form of air, for if it were, the air would be destroyed when light is withdrawn.

column2: Hence it cannot be the substantial form of the sun.
column3: Hence it cannot be the substantial form of the sun

column2: We must say, then, that as heat is an active quality consequent on the substantial form of fire, so light is an active quality consequent on the substantial form of the sun, or of another body that is of itself luminous, if there is any such body.
column3: We must say, then, that as heat is an active quality consequent on the substantial form of fire, so light is an active quality consequent on the substantial form of the sun, or of another body that is of itself luminous, if there is any such body.

column2: A proof of this is that the rays of different stars produce different effects according to the diverse natures of bodies.
column3: A proof of this is that the rays of different stars produce different effects according to the diverse natures of bodies.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: Since quality is consequent upon substantial form, the mode in which the subject receives a quality differs as the mode differs in which a subject receives a substantial form.
column3: Reply o b j. one: Since quality is consequent upon substantial form, the mode in which the subject receives a quality differs as the mode differs in which a subject receives a substantial form.

column2: For when matter receives its form perfectly, the qualities consequent upon the form are firm and enduring; as when, for instance, water is converted into fire.
column3: For when matter receives its form perfectly, the qualities consequent upon the form are firm and enduring; as when, for instance, water is converted into fire.

column2: When, however, substantial form is received imperfectly, so as to be, as it were, in process of being received, rather than fully impressed, the consequent quality lasts for a time but is not permanent; as may be seen when water which has been heated returns in time to its natural state.
column3: When, however, substantial form is received imperfectly, so as to be, as it were, in process of being received, rather than fully impressed, the consequent quality lasts for a time but is not permanent; as may be seen when water which has been heated returns in time to its natural state.

column2: But light is not produced by the transmutation of matter, as though matter were in receipt of a substantial form, and light were a certain inception of substantial form.
column3: But light is not produced by the transmutation of matter, as though matter were in receipt of a substantial form, and light were a certain inception of substantial form.

column2: For this reason light disappears on the disappearance of its active cause.
column3: For this reason light disappears on the disappearance of its active cause.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: It is accidental to light not to have a contrary, forasmuch as it is the natural quality of the first corporeal cause of change, which is itself removed from contrariety.
column3: Reply o b j. two: It is accidental to light not to have a contrary, forasmuch as it is the natural quality of the first corporeal cause of change, which is itself removed from contrariety.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: As heat acts towards perfecting the form of fire, as an instrumental cause, by virtue of the substantial form, so does light act instrumentally, by virtue of the heavenly bodies, towards producing substantial forms; and towards rendering colors actually visible, inasmuch as it is a quality of the first sensible body. _______________________
column3: Reply o b j. three: As heat acts towards perfecting the form of fire, as an instrumental cause, by virtue of the substantial form, so does light act instrumentally, by virtue of the heavenly bodies, towards producing substantial forms; and towards rendering colors actually visible, inasmuch as it is a quality of the first sensible body. , blank ,

column2: FOURTH ARTICLE [I, Q. 67, Art. 4]
column3: FOURTH ARTICLE [I, q sixty seven, Art. four]

column2: Whether the Production of Light Is Fittingly Assigned to the First Day?
column3: Whether the Production of Light Is Fittingly Assigned to the First Day?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the production of light is not fittingly assigned to the first day.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the production of light is not fittingly assigned to the first day.

column2: For light, as stated above (A. 3), is a quality.
column3: For light, as stated above (A. three), is a quality.

column2: But qualities are accidents, and as such should have, not the first, but a subordinate place.
column3: But qualities are accidents, and as such should have, not the first, but a subordinate place.

column2: The production of light, then, ought not to be assigned to the first day.
column3: The production of light, then, ought not to be assigned to the first day.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, it is light that distinguishes night from day, and this is effected by the sun, which is recorded as having been made on the fourth day.
column3: o b j. two: Further, it is light that distinguishes night from day, and this is effected by the sun, which is recorded as having been made on the fourth day.

column2: Therefore the production of light could not have been on the first day.
column3: Therefore the production of light could not have been on the first day.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, night and day are brought about by the circular movement of a luminous body.
column3: o b j. three: Further, night and day are brought about by the circular movement of a luminous body.

column2: But movement of this kind is an attribute of the firmament, and we read that the firmament was made on the second day.
column3: But movement of this kind is an attribute of the firmament, and we read that the firmament was made on the second day.

column2: Therefore the production of light, dividing night from day, ought not to be assigned to the first day.
column3: Therefore the production of light, dividing night from day, ought not to be assigned to the first day.

column2: Obj. 4: Further, if it be said that spiritual light is here spoken of, it may be replied that the light made on the first day dispels the darkness.
column3: o b j. four: Further, if it be said that spiritual light is here spoken of, it may be replied that the light made on the first day dispels the darkness.

column2: But in the beginning spiritual darkness was not, for even the demons were in the beginning good, as has been shown (Q. 63, A. 5).
column3: But in the beginning spiritual darkness was not, for even the demons were in the beginning good, as has been shown (Q. sixty three, a five).

column2: Therefore the production of light ought not to be assigned to the first day.
column3: Therefore the production of light ought not to be assigned to the first day.

column2: _On the contrary,_ That without which there could not be day, must have been made on the first day.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore That without which there could not be day, must have been made on the first day.

column2: But there can be no day without light.
column3: But there can be no day without light.

column2: Therefore light must have been made on the first day.
column3: Therefore light must have been made on the first day.

column2: _I answer that,_ There are two opinions as to the production of light. Augustine seems to say (De Civ.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore There are two opinions as to the production of light. Augustine seems to say (De Civ.

column2: Dei xi, 9,33) that Moses could not have fittingly passed over the production of the spiritual creature, and therefore when we read, "In the beginning God created heaven and earth," a spiritual nature as yet formless is to be understood by the word "heaven," and formless matter of the corporeal creature by the word "earth." And spiritual nature was formed first, as being of higher dignity than corporeal.
column3: Dei xi, nine,thirty three) that Moses could not have fittingly passed over the production of the spiritual creature, and therefore when we read, "In the beginning God created heaven and earth," a spiritual nature as yet formless is to be understood by the word "heaven," and formless matter of the corporeal creature by the word "earth." And spiritual nature was formed first, as being of higher dignity than corporeal.

column2: The forming, therefore, of this spiritual nature is signified by the production of light, that is to say, of spiritual light.
column3: The forming, therefore, of this spiritual nature is signified by the production of light, that is to say, of spiritual light.

column2: For a spiritual nature receives its form by the enlightenment whereby it is led to adhere to the Word of God.
column3: For a spiritual nature receives its form by the enlightenment whereby it is led to adhere to the Word of God.

column2: Other writers think that the production of spiritual creatures was purposely omitted by Moses, and give various reasons.
column3: Other writers think that the production of spiritual creatures was purposely omitted by Moses, and give various reasons.

column2: Basil [*Hom.
column3: Basil [asterisk Hom.

column2: i in Hexaem.] says that Moses begins his narrative from the beginning of time which belongs to sensible things; but that the spiritual or angelic creation is passed over, as created beforehand.
column3: i in Hexaem.] says that Moses begins his narrative from the beginning of time which belongs to sensible things; but that the spiritual or angelic creation is passed over, as created beforehand.

column2: Chrysostom [*Hom. ii in Genes.] gives as a reason for the omission that Moses was addressing an ignorant people, to whom material things alone appealed, and whom he was endeavoring to withdraw from the service of idols.
column3: Chrysostom [asterisk Hom. ii in Genes.] gives as a reason for the omission that Moses was addressing an ignorant people, to whom material things alone appealed, and whom he was endeavoring to withdraw from the service of idols.

column2: It would have been to them a pretext for idolatry if he had spoken to them of natures spiritual in substance and nobler than all corporeal creatures; for they would have paid them Divine worship, since they were prone to worship as gods even the sun, moon, and stars, which was forbidden them (Deut. 4).
column3: It would have been to them a pretext for idolatry if he had spoken to them of natures spiritual in substance and nobler than all corporeal creatures; for they would have paid them Divine worship, since they were prone to worship as gods even the sun, moon, and stars, which was forbidden them (Deut. four).

column2: But mention is made of several kinds of formlessness, in regard to the corporeal creature.
column3: But mention is made of several kinds of formlessness, in regard to the corporeal creature.

column2: One is where we read that "the earth was void and empty," and another where it is said that "darkness was upon the face of the deep." Now it seems to be required, for two reasons, that the formlessness of darkness should be removed first of all by the production of light.
column3: One is where we read that "the earth was void and empty," and another where it is said that "darkness was upon the face of the deep." Now it seems to be required, for two reasons, that the formlessness of darkness should be removed first of all by the production of light.

column2: In the first place because light is a quality of the first body, as was stated (A. 3), and thus by means of light it was fitting that the world should first receive its form.
column3: In the first place because light is a quality of the first body, as was stated (A. three), and thus by means of light it was fitting that the world should first receive its form.

column2: The second reason is because light is a common quality.
column3: The second reason is because light is a common quality.

column2: For light is common to terrestrial and celestial bodies.
column3: For light is common to terrestrial and celestial bodies.

column2: But as in knowledge we proceed from general principles, so do we in work of every kind.
column3: But as in knowledge we proceed from general principles, so do we in work of every kind.

column2: For the living thing is generated before the animal, and the animal before the man, as is shown in _De Gener.
column3: For the living thing is generated before the animal, and the animal before the man, as is shown in underscore De Gener.

column2: Anim._ ii, 3.
column3: Anim.underscore ii, three.

column2: It was fitting, then, as an evidence of the Divine wisdom, that among the works of distinction the production of light should take first place, since light is a form of the primary body, and because it is more common quality.
column3: It was fitting, then, as an evidence of the Divine wisdom, that among the works of distinction the production of light should take first place, since light is a form of the primary body, and because it is more common quality.

column2: Basil [*Hom. ii in Hexaem.], indeed, adds a third reason: that all other things are made manifest by light.
column3: Basil [asterisk Hom. ii in Hexaem.], indeed, adds a third reason: that all other things are made manifest by light.

column2: And there is yet a fourth, already touched upon in the objections; that day cannot be unless light exists, which was made therefore on the first day.
column3: And there is yet a fourth, already touched upon in the objections; that day cannot be unless light exists, which was made therefore on the first day.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: According to the opinion of those who hold that the formlessness of matter preceded its form in duration, matter must be held to have been created at the beginning with substantial forms, afterwards receiving those that are accidental, among which light holds the first place.
column3: Reply o b j. one: According to the opinion of those who hold that the formlessness of matter preceded its form in duration, matter must be held to have been created at the beginning with substantial forms, afterwards receiving those that are accidental, among which light holds the first place.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: In the opinion of some the light here spoken of was a kind of luminous nebula, and that on the making of the sun this returned to the matter of which it had been formed.
column3: Reply o b j. two: In the opinion of some the light here spoken of was a kind of luminous nebula, and that on the making of the sun this returned to the matter of which it had been formed.

column2: But this cannot well be maintained, as in the beginning of Genesis Holy Scripture records the institution of that order of nature which henceforth is to endure.
column3: But this cannot well be maintained, as in the beginning of genesis Holy Scripture records the institution of that order of nature which henceforth is to endure.

column2: We cannot, then, say that what was made at that time afterwards ceased to exist.
column3: We cannot, then, say that what was made at that time afterwards ceased to exist.

column2: Others, therefore, held that this luminous nebula continues in existence, but so closely attached to the sun as to be indistinguishable.
column3: Others, therefore, held that this luminous nebula continues in existence, but so closely attached to the sun as to be indistinguishable.

column2: But this is as much as to say that it is superfluous, whereas none of God's works have been made in vain.
column3: But this is as much as to say that it is superfluous, whereas none of God's works have been made in vain.

column2: On this account it is held by some that the sun's body was made out of this nebula.
column3: On this account it is held by some that the sun's body was made out of this nebula.

column2: This, too, is impossible to those at least who believe that the sun is different in its nature from the four elements, and naturally incorruptible.
column3: This, too, is impossible to those at least who believe that the sun is different in its nature from the four elements, and naturally incorruptible.

column2: For in that case its matter cannot take on another form.
column3: For in that case its matter cannot take on another form.

column2: I answer, then, with Dionysius (Div.
column3: I answer, then, with Dionysius (d i v.

column2: Nom. iv), that the light was the sun's light, formless as yet, being already the solar substance, and possessing illuminative power in a general way, to which was afterwards added the special and determinative power required to produce determinate effects.
column3: Nom. i v), that the light was the sun's light, formless as yet, being already the solar substance, and possessing illuminative power in a general way, to which was afterwards added the special and determinative power required to produce determinate effects.

column2: Thus, then, in the production of this light a triple distinction was made between light and darkness. First, as to the cause, forasmuch as in the substance of the sun we have the cause of light, and in the opaque nature of the earth the cause of darkness.
column3: Thus, then, in the production of this light a triple distinction was made between light and darkness. First, as to the cause, forasmuch as in the substance of the sun we have the cause of light, and in the opaque nature of the earth the cause of darkness.

column2: Secondly, as to place, for in one hemisphere there was light, in the other darkness.
column3: Secondly, as to place, for in one hemisphere there was light, in the other darkness.

column2: Thirdly, as to time; because there was light for one and darkness for another in the same hemisphere; and this is signified by the words, "He called the light day, and the darkness night."
column3: Thirdly, as to time; because there was light for one and darkness for another in the same hemisphere; and this is signified by the words, "He called the light day, and the darkness night."

column2: Reply Obj. 3: Basil says (Hom. ii in Hexaem.) that day and night were then caused by expansion and contraction of light, rather than by movement.
column3: Reply o b j. three: Basil says (Hom. ii in Hexaem.) that day and night were then caused by expansion and contraction of light, rather than by movement.

column2: But Augustine objects to this (Gen. ad lit.
column3: But Augustine objects to this (Gen. ad lit.

column2: i), that there was no reason for this vicissitude of expansion and contraction since there were neither men nor animals on the earth at that time, for whose service this was required.
column3: i), that there was no reason for this vicissitude of expansion and contraction since there were neither men nor animals on the earth at that time, for whose service this was required.

column2: Nor does the nature of a luminous body seem to admit of the withdrawal of light, so long as the body is actually present; though this might be effected by a miracle.
column3: Nor does the nature of a luminous body seem to admit of the withdrawal of light, so long as the body is actually present; though this might be effected by a miracle.

column2: As to this, however, Augustine remarks (Gen. ad lit.
column3: As to this, however, Augustine remarks (Gen. ad lit.

column2: i) that in the first founding of the order of nature we must not look for miracles, but for what is in accordance with nature.
column3: i) that in the first founding of the order of nature we must not look for miracles, but for what is in accordance with nature.

column2: We hold, then, that the movement of the heavens is twofold.
column3: We hold, then, that the movement of the heavens is twofold.

column2: Of these movements, one is common to the entire heaven, and is the cause of day and night.
column3: Of these movements, one is common to the entire heaven, and is the cause of day and night.

column2: This, as it seems, had its beginning on the first day.
column3: This, as it seems, had its beginning on the first day.

column2: The other varies in proportion as it affects various bodies, and by its variations is the cause of the succession of days, months, and years.
column3: The other varies in proportion as it affects various bodies, and by its variations is the cause of the succession of days, months, and years.

column2: Thus it is, that in the account of the first day the distinction between day and night alone is mentioned; this distinction being brought about by the common movement of the heavens.
column3: Thus it is, that in the account of the first day the distinction between day and night alone is mentioned; this distinction being brought about by the common movement of the heavens.

column2: The further distinction into successive days, seasons, and years recorded as begun on the fourth day, in the words, "let them be for seasons, and for days, and years" is due to proper movements.
column3: The further distinction into successive days, seasons, and years recorded as begun on the fourth day, in the words, "let them be for seasons, and for days, and years" is due to proper movements.

column2: Reply Obj. 4: As Augustine teaches (Confess. xii; Gen. ad lit.
column3: Reply o b j. four: As Augustine teaches (Confess. x i i; Gen. ad lit.

column2: 1, 15), formlessness did not precede forms in duration; and so we must understand the production of light to signify the formation of spiritual creatures, not, indeed, with the perfection of glory, in which they were not created, but with the perfection of grace, which they possessed from their creation as said above (Q. 62, A. 3).
column3: one, fifteen), formlessness did not precede forms in duration; and so we must understand the production of light to signify the formation of spiritual creatures, not, indeed, with the perfection of glory, in which they were not created, but with the perfection of grace, which they possessed from their creation as said above (Q. sixty two, a three).

column2: Thus the division of light from darkness will denote the distinction of the spiritual creature from other created things as yet without form. But if all created things received their form at the same time, the darkness must be held to mean the spiritual darkness of the wicked, not as existing from the beginning but such as God foresaw would exist. _______________________
column3: Thus the division of light from darkness will denote the distinction of the spiritual creature from other created things as yet without form. But if all created things received their form at the same time, the darkness must be held to mean the spiritual darkness of the wicked, not as existing from the beginning but such as God foresaw would exist. , blank ,
